snippet: Experts in neuroscience, genetics and social work discussed emerging research on what happens to a child’s brain before it is fully formed, and how children who seem broken can be made whole.
abstract: Jim Dwyer About New York column examines negative effect of environmental stress and poverty on developing brains, particularly in context of New York City school children exposed to abuse and dysfunction; notes efforts of experts panel called Poverty, the Brain and Mental Health, which provides social services in New York's schools.
lead_paragraph: Experts in neuroscience, genetics and social work discussed emerging research on what happens to a child’s brain before it is fully formed, and how children who seem broken can be made whole.

headline.main: Studying How Poverty Keeps Hurting Young Minds, and What to Do About It
headline.print_headline: How Poverty Keeps Hurting Young Minds

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: National Center for Children in Poverty
